body: ‘Scary, intimidating. Are these the words we want to be using to describe how our kids are using technology?” asks the ever-enthralling Aleks Krotoski in Changeling. Previous episodes of Radio 4’s absorbing Digital Human series have focused on taste, body and mind and they’re all worth a listen. Now, talk turns to the contentious issue of children being better at using technology than their parents. Krotoski always brings out the human emotion behind the digital story and she has no problem firing up the most paranoid part of a parent’s brain with this debate. That moment when you realise your child can unlock your tablet also unlocks peace and quiet, but what happens when the terror of your three-year-old overtaking your technical skills kicks in? Big questions are asked: if these devices aren’t real, does that mean the people using them aren’t feeling real emotions? Surely anyone who has ever witnessed the glee a child experiences watching Disney figures being unboxed on YouTube would beg to differ. Some of the theories touted seem a bit far-fetched, unless of course your concern over your toddler being able to swipe really does mask your fear of children. Beware, these little creatures have the power to make you obsolete one day. Grim existential thinking aside, Krotoski illustrates that technology is changing so quickly it’s impossible for the older generation to keep up. Is Snapchat that much different from swapping notes in class? The fear that parents can’t give their children the benefit of their experience if they’re not exactly sure what it is they’re doing is real. How parenting has changed in the last 10 years is perfectly summed up by one dad of a toddler, who once had grand plans to “read him stories and sing him songs”. Then reality set in. “I think after about two weeks we realised it wasn’t going to be remotely possible,” he says. “It very quickly drains your sanity.” Busy lives leave little time for Baa-Baa-Blacksheeping, but the guilt lies heavy. Alicia Blum-Ross touches on how the no-screen rule is touted in the same way as the breastfeeding debate: stick to it and your child will be OK. But with screen-time being such a big part of modern life, maybe it’s time to bend the rules.
